audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker expressing surprise about the early timing of a lunar eclipse in 2015. He then describes connecting a camera module to a zoom lens to capture the astronomical event. The clip ends with a single brief, distinct "click" sound.

A male speaker explains that for the linkage, the rear plastic cover of a lens has to be surface ground and drilled with an 8 mm center hole. He then says that the lens of the camera module has to be removed. He describes placing the camera board on a flat surface and using a piece of depron as a bedding layer, and keeping it in place with a caliper. The speaker then describes using a stick of cold hot glue to press on the lens and unscrew it, or using a pencil with a rubber at the rear end. There is a brief sound.

The clip begins with a calm, male voice explaining "how you can use some hot glue at the corners of the board to mount the camera module on the plastic cover". He transitions to discussing "the flange focal distance" and how "the length between the rear of the lens to the plane of the light sensitive chip has to be considered to record focused images". He continues, describing how he "tried several spacers and found that with 20 millimeters, best", before concluding that "it's no perfect solution, but on the afternoon before the event, it was the best camera adapter I could create". Following this, a low-frequency hum becomes audible and remains present until the end of the clip.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating that a "reasonably priced tripod is also no good solution for astronomical observations", delivered in a neutral tone. This transitions into another male speaker stating "as you can see, you get enormous clearance for your money" in a conversational tone. A sound then occurs that could be characterized as a clanking or metallic noise, abruptly ending the clip.

The clip begins with a male speaker mentioning that "The Raspberry Camera can't control the aperture or the lens". He then adds that "to get an aperture of less than four", the lens can be removed while the aperture is triggered. Following this, the speaker describes how "the light sensor used with the Raspberry Pi camera module is clearly smaller than that of a standard camera".

The audio clip begins with a speaker, a male, stating that a "crop factor of approximately nine" is achieved, leading to a "focal length of this zoom lens" reaching "up to 2,700 millimeters" in a factual tone. He then describes getting "a total view of the moon" when the zoom is adjusted to approximately 130 millimeters, which equals 1,200 millimeters with a Raspberry camera module.

The audio features a single male speaker with a thoughtful and slightly critical tone, discussing the challenges of using a home-built telescope to observe the moon. He acknowledges the surprisingly good results given the simple construction, but notes its limitations. He mentions the moon's movement and the difficulty of tracking it with a cheap tripod. The speaker notes when a lunar eclipse started. Finally the speech fades away.

The clip begins with a single male speaker asking a question about the movement of Earth's shadow. The speaker continues in an informative tone, describing the moon's orbit and its distances from Earth. The speech concludes with "and," followed by what sounds like background music with an indistinct style or purpose.

A male voice provides context about the distance of the moon during a lunar eclipse, noting it was very close to the smallest possible separation. He also mentions the average separation between Earth and Moon increases each year. He then says "The moon is nippled by the Earth's Umbra." He follows with something unintelligible.

The audio features a single male speaker discussing the recording of a sequence at "15 minutes past 3." He then describes the contrast of the video images being too low, making it difficult to see the reddish part of the moon's surface shadowed by the earth. He mentions recording the sequences with an aperture of 11, an exposure time of 25 milliseconds set with the software parameter "shutter speed," and setting the light sensitivity to ISO 100 to reduce image noise.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating the third sequence was recorded at a specific time, then describing how the moon was covered by the Earth's umbra after about 30 minutes. The speaker continues, explaining that the next sequences appear "rickety" because he opened a window to follow the moon's movement, which caused optical distortions as warm air escaped.

The audio clip starts with a calm male voice stating scientific facts about the Moon orbiting the Earth and its mass relative to Earth. The tone is informative and measured. The speaker then describes the shape of the illuminated surface as a "narrow crescent." He admits failing to record the moon's surface in the Earth's umbra, mentioning appropriate values for light sensitivity, aperture, and exposure time. He concludes that he needs to upgrade his equipment for the next lunar eclipse. The clip ends abruptly with the sound of electronic static.

The audio features a single male speaker, calmly explaining that "just a small fraction of the moon surface is still outside the Earth's umbra" and later noting, "the moon starts leaving the umbra". The speaker then observes that "the celestial object is above the roofs of my small hometown from my point of view."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how the temperature dropped and caused convection, also mentioning the moon's proximity to the Earth's horizon and the visibility of the moon's scintillation. The speaker continues, stating, "the more the moon exits the umbra of the Earth, the more you notice the scintillation." He then indicates that the sequence was recorded at a certain time. The speaker then shares their observation point coordinates and that the times are given in Central European Summer Time, which is plus two hours from Universal Time Code.

A male speaker notes that it's 10 minutes past 6, and more than half of the moon's surface is visible. A plane then passes into view. The speaker adds that Frankfurt Airport is only 80 kilometers away.  The speaker notes that the plane is moving horizontally rather than climbing. The speaker then discusses that he turned the telescope on the tripod in order to capture a video of the moon as it moves horizontally across the screen. He says that it is hard to adjust the tripod to track the moon. The speaker goes on to say that the moon is also moving vertically towards the Earth's horizon. He concludes that he is able to see the Earth's shadow on the bottom right of the moon.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker saying, "At 20 minutes past six, the last but one sequence was recorded." He continues in a similar tone, describing recording the moon and plans to improve equipment, noting "preferably with better results." He mentions the next total lunar eclipse visible from his hometown will occur in July 2018, giving "adequate setup time." The next recorded sequence was at "26 minutes past six", which he follows by explaining that "The moon leaves the umbra" and that the eclipse ended at 27 minutes past six. He informs listeners that "You can get the built instruction of my telescope on the project page." He signs off saying, "Thanks for watching and I'll be back."
